title: Modeling a Non-Periodic Context-Exponential Function, Part B

content.description:
Each spring a particular species of fish migrates up a river. “Migrates” refers to moving from one region to another according to the seasons. In 2015 (<math alttext="t equals 0" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>), there were <math alttext="4500" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>4500</mn> </math> fish that migrated up the river. In 2021 (<math alttext="t equals 6" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>), there were <math alttext="900" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>900</mn></math> fish that migrated up the river.  

For <math alttext="t greater or equal than 0" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, the number of fish that migrated up the river can be modeled by the function <math alttext="F" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>F</mi></math> given by <math alttext="F open parentheses t close parentheses equals a b to the power of t" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>F</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>b</mi><mi>t</mi></msup></math>, where <math alttext="F open parentheses t close parentheses" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>F</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced></math> is the number of fish that migrated up the river in year <math alttext="t" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi></math>, and <math alttext="t" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi></math> is the number of years since 2015.
content.question:
Part B

(i) Use the given data to find the average rate of change of the number of fish that migrated up the river, in fish per year, from <math alttext="t equals 0"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> to <math alttext="t equals 6"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math> years. Express your answer as a decimal approximation. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(ii) Use the average rate of change found in (i) to estimate the number of fish that migrated up the river in 2017 (<math alttext="t equals 2"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>). Show the work that leads to your answer.

(iii) Let <math alttext="A subscript t"><msub><mi>A</mi><mi>t</mi></msub></math> represent the estimate of the number of fish that migrated up the river using the average rate of change found in (i). For <math alttext="A subscript 2"><msub><mi>A</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, found in (ii), it can be shown that <math alttext="A subscript 2 greater than F open parentheses 2 close parentheses"><msub><mi>A</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mi>F</mi><mfenced><mn>2</mn></mfenced></math>. Explain why, in general, <math alttext="A subscript t greater than F open parentheses t close parentheses"> <msub> <mi>A</mi> <mi>t</mi> </msub> <mo>></mo> <mi>F</mi> <mfenced> <mi>t</mi> </mfenced> </math> for all <math alttext="t"><mi>t</mi></math>, where <math alttext="0 less than t less than 6"><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo><</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.

frqParts.text:
Part B

(i) Use the given data to find the average rate of change of the number of fish that migrated up the river, in fish per year, from <math alttext="t equals 0"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> to <math alttext="t equals 6"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math> years. Express your answer as a decimal approximation. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(ii) Use the average rate of change found in (i) to estimate the number of fish that migrated up the river in 2017 (<math alttext="t equals 2"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>). Show the work that leads to your answer.

(iii) Let <math alttext="A subscript t"><msub><mi>A</mi><mi>t</mi></msub></math> represent the estimate of the number of fish that migrated up the river using the average rate of change found in (i). For <math alttext="A subscript 2"><msub><mi>A</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, found in (ii), it can be shown that <math alttext="A subscript 2 greater than F open parentheses 2 close parentheses"><msub><mi>A</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mi>F</mi><mfenced><mn>2</mn></mfenced></math>. Explain why, in general, <math alttext="A subscript t greater than F open parentheses t close parentheses"> <msub> <mi>A</mi> <mi>t</mi> </msub> <mo>></mo> <mi>F</mi> <mfenced> <mi>t</mi> </mfenced> </math> for all <math alttext="t"><mi>t</mi></math>, where <math alttext="0 less than t less than 6"><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo><</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.

topic.text: 1.3: Rates of Change in Linear and Quadratic Functions

skill.text: Skill 1.B: Express functions, equations, or expressions in analytically equivalent forms that are useful in a given mathematical or applied context.
